name: Mobilization Graphics
philosophy: PROVOKE: Design to evoke emotional response and urgency. CONTRAST: Stark visual opposition that clarifies stakes. BOLD: High-contrast, attention-grabbing compositions that cut through noise. CLEAR: One unmistakable message per visualization. ACTION: Every graphic implies 'what you should do next'. SHAREABLE: Optimized for social media impact and virality. RIGHTEOUS: Frame the issue as moral imperative, not neutral analysis. This is advocacy design—persuade, don't just inform.

typography.primary_font: Impact, Helvetica Black, Arial Black, sans-serif

layout_principles: One dominant visual element—no visual democracy
Text should SHOUT—use all caps for key messages
Arrows and visual direction guide the eye to the point
Use stark visual metaphors (chains, scales, clocks, etc.)
Red for danger/urgency, gold for hope/value
annotation_style: Bold callouts, emphatic arrows, stark labels. Frame tensions with contrasting colors. Short, punchy phrases. Imperative mood: 'Stop this' 'Act now' 'Share this'. Statistics as shocking numbers in large type. Appeal to authority when useful. No nuance—clarity over complexity.
gemini_modifiers:
STYLE INSTRUCTIONS (Mobilization Graphics):

TONE:
- This is NOT neutral analysis—take a clear position
- Frame as URGENCY that demands response
- Use power dynamics explicitly
- Imply urgency: 'This is happening NOW'

VISUAL APPROACH:
- HIGH CONTRAST: Red/Black/White dominant palette
- BOLD typography: Impact font, all caps for key messages
- ONE CLEAR MESSAGE per visual
- Stark visual metaphors: chains, scales, targets, crosshairs, clocks
- Dramatic color coding for opposing sides
- Dramatic lighting effects
- Fill the frame—no empty space

COMPOSITION:
- Social media optimized (square or 4:5 ratio)
- Works at thumbnail size
- Central focal point
- Call to action visible

influences.tradition_note: This approach draws from a century of political graphic design—Soviet constructivism, labor movement posters, civil rights graphics, and contemporary digital activism. The tradition prioritizes emotional impact and call-to-action over balanced presentation, treating design as a tool for social change.

exemplars.name: Soviet Constructivists (Rodchenko, El Lissitzky)
exemplars.contribution: Revolutionary graphic language: bold geometry, limited palette, dynamic composition

exemplars.name: Shepard Fairey
exemplars.contribution: Contemporary synthesis of street art and political graphics (OBEY, Hope poster)

exemplars.name: Emory Douglas
exemplars.contribution: Black Panther Party graphics—urgent, provocative, community-centered

key_works: ACT UP and AIDS activism graphics
